section.text: Good morning, guys, and thanks for your time this morning. A first question just around what's going on with customers on recoveries and settlements and pricing which is all kind of being put together in the same basket in discussions often from your suppliers and automakers, but I'm just curious, as you're going through the process of getting recoveries, is some of these one-time in nature or do you think is kind of a little bit of a paradigm shift here and what's going on with pricing with some of your customers already pass-throughs and indexing, I just trying to understand this is a true-ups or is this a change in attitude going forward? And I think we've heard from some of the automakers, they didn't realize how much the volatility was impacting their suppliers which is intriguing, because they're in the middle of it, and some of this stuff was a result of making up for some of the inefficiencies around volatility and then as schedules normalized maybe these recoveries might not be as great going forward. So, what is your take on this?

Hi, John. So, some of it is in price, some of it is one-time. But it's true that when we negotiate and when we talk to our customers, they realize that this is a big hit and that big it may be here to stay. So, I expect that for 2023 we'll have ongoing discussions with our customers around inflation. What's important is that we made sure that the nature of the recovery that we get from our customer-base match pretty much the nature of the help that we are giving to our supply base, and that will be our goal also going forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "74b26a64-f871-4dfd-b9bf-8e7f5386699d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And maybe John I'll just jump in and add on the one-time nature of certain elements of recoveries that we generated in the quarter, included in that 10.8% margin that we posted was about a 40-basis-point margin benefit arising from retroactive pricing recoveries partially offset by retroactive supplier cost. So, there was a little bit of a tailwind in the quarter about 40 basis-points coming from that in our margin.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "4cc4e841-e441-46d8-abcc-c6cb16fa0827", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: So that 40-basis-point is the net of those two, Kevin is that correct?
That's the net of the two.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "bc526eb8-d79d-4edc-8959-65fc478f615e", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. And then just really one quick follow-up on Slide 8, it looks like as you mentioned you did $4 billion combined here versus the total target of $4.5 billion, so you're over-performing on organic and a little bit underperforming on M&A so far. I mean, as you think about this going forward is it necessary to catch-up on M&A or chase things if you're winning more and more on organic and it might get you to your total goal more on the organic side as opposed to the M&A side? Or is there something specifically on the technology side that might not be as associated with a dollar number here that you're trying to get to in M&A instead of just bolstering the total revenue number? How do you think the balance of these two is really key question.

So, first I would say that I'm very proud of where we are, 18 months into Charging Forward we're already 45% on our way into a 5-year plan, so very proud of that. From an M&A perspective, we are focusing on is building capabilities, products leadership and scale from grid to wheel in that, that's the target. And so, we're not chasing a number, we're chasing that type of mindset, really.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "70c1b4b5-6721-45b1-8db8-b81ee59760f3", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. That's helpful. Thank you very much, guys.

Good morning. Thanks for taking the questions. Next to the traction on those pricing recoveries, just illustratively, how should we, think about rollover benefits for 2023 at this point as given the timing of these actions, it seems reasonable to assume a couple of points benefit for next year, maybe you could comment on that. And I think Fred you mentioned that some of the recovery discussions would remain dynamic, so maybe you can help us think about timing of potential further recoveries as we look over the coming quarters.

I'll start. As it relates to 2023, as we look at 2022 and the recoveries and the cost that we've been incurring, we don't have an expectation that we're going to ultimately fully offset all the cost that's come into the P&L, we've been negotiating recoveries to defray a portion of those cost increases, a substantial portion, but not entirely, so we're bearing some of that cost. So, as you look ahead to 2023, I wouldn't necessarily look there at there being a tailwind to our margin because we don't ultimately expect to offset all the cost increase that we're incurring in 2022.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "913a3aee-749e-44db-9b1e-1ee789dcd986", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Right. I mean the question is to the topline that there'll be some benefit to the topline from those recoveries rolling over.

Yeah, I mean to the extent that those -- that the inflationary impacts continue as we head into 2023 and that pricing needs to stay in place to defray the continued inflationary cost, if that's where it goes, then we would expect to continue to generate that topline benefit within our revenue. If you just take a step-back, if you look at our outgrowth for the year, we are delivering about 9% outgrowth underlying our guidance, a little bit north of 9% and just under 4% of that is coming from these, the customer pricing recoveries associated with material inflation costs which means that we have 5 points or so of out-growth coming from everything else, but that's the way to think about what's happening in 2022 and then you can make assumptions about how you expect the inflationary environment to play-out in '23 and how that nearly 4% pricing would carry over.
Right. And then just to clarify again, have your expectations of that material cost inflation changed relative to last quarter, or are we still looking at the same number?

They have. I think last quarter we were expecting that the contribution to our outgrowth from the pricing recoveries was closer to 3%, I think now we're suggesting in our guidance that the full year impact of those pricing recoveries is a little bit under 4% and that's part of the reason that you see in my remarks that the net impact that we're now expecting on the year for material cost inflation is down from our prior guide, it's $110 million to $120 million which is a $35 million improvement from what we guided to last quarter, and it's being driven by improved customer pricing actions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "67e7cdc5-6ede-4ab4-847f-0ba5693a3e92", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: All right. Great. Nice to see that that improving. And then I guess sort of shifting to Fred some of your commentary around the management of the portfolio and how you view M&A. That certainly makes sense at a high level strategically, I'm curious to know what the tenor and the activity within the pipeline is like at this point, obviously there's still a volatile production environment and lots of challenges for nascent EV businesses, but maybe you can talk a little bit about the depth and the actionability of the pipeline at this point.

Right. It's very active, we are engaged with a certain number of companies of targets. So, focusing on the same things. Again, scale on products from grid to wheel product leadership which -- and I mean by that essentially the around efficiency of moving electrons across that grid to wheel and potentially new products too in the field of EV. So, it's pretty active.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "cdc4ada1-5499-420b-8f5a-76e67d27a29a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. Terrific. Thank you.

Great. Thanks for taking my questions. You mentioned at the midpoint the inflationary costs were down about $35 million, if I look at operating margins, the outlook for the year is still fairly flat. It looks like sales down just a bit at the midpoint of guidance. What is offsetting that underlying $35 million of good news?

Yeah, I think it depends when you look at the guide. I mean, if you look at the top-end of our guide one of the things to keep in mind as we took industry production down, and so that has an impact on organic growth in the high-end of our guidance range and then at the low-end of our guidance range as you look at Q4 it's actually not being offset, it's really flowing through that $35 million benefit which is why we raised the bottom-end from 9.8% to 10%.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "121be18b-bf10-4076-a90e-894e4e28c953", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. And then as I look into the implied guidance, it implies sort of a sales decline into Q4. I think, like IHS has light-vehicle production up, are you not seeing the market up, is it just a FX that's washing all that out, is it commercial offsetting some of that, what's kind of causing the softness into Q4?

Sequentially, going into Q4 we do have an almost $90 million FX headwind Q3 to Q4, so that is a big piece of what's impacting revenue, and then the range of outlook that we have going from basically with underlying our $15.4 billion to our $15.7 billion revenue guide is at the lower-end and at the midpoint some pressure on organic growth, sequentially.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "a638efa1-e253-4f62-9e76-79b4cbfeaaee", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And then just lastly the $110 million, $120 million impact, how much was in Q3 and how much would be left for Q4 as headwinds so we can model that? Thanks.

We didn't break that out in terms of the Q3 and Q4, but because of the nature of some of the retroactive recoveries on a net basis that we generated in Q3 really mitigated the impact on Q3 relative to the other quarters that we've seen, so in Q3 we had a negative $8 million impact. I think as we look to Q4 it's on a year-over-year basis a little bit larger because we don't expect the same size of retroactive-related benefits of what we got in Q3.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "943cd068-aab0-40b2-a48a-db6212235124", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Got it. Alright. Thank you very much for taking my question.

Thanks so much, guys. Maybe we can start on actually some of the ICE products and particularly the margin, the revenue of fuel injection aftermarket have been quite good and we haven't really discussed sort of individual segment margins some of them are new, maybe you could just talk about some of the strength you can see and ways to think about some of the segment margins for fuel injection or aftermarket on a go-forward basis?

Chris, I think the teams done a formidable job right after the closing of the Delphi transaction to turn this business around, if you go back, the Fuel System margins that we think the business back and what it is now, it's pretty, pretty good, both on the Fuel Systems side and aftermarket systems.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "15956b29-70a8-42af-95e1-df0fc5c14452", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Perfect. And then anything -- is there any extraordinaries in sort of some of the margins we're seeing Q3 in terms of some of the benefits on a one-time price recovery, we're just trying to trend it out and it's been pretty variable on a margin perspective over the first three quarters. So just anything qualitative on just the ratio of margin here what sort of normalized.

Yeah, I mean I think it's hard to compare quarter-to-quarter those because there's been such volatility, Q2 obviously we were pretty significantly impacted by a combination of revenue being relatively low as well as material cost inflation and the recoveries hasn't entirely been kicking-in yet. As you go to Q3, you see obviously we delivered over $4 billion of revenue in the quarter and a strong level of customer recoveries and so you're seeing a lot of swings quarter-to-quarter right now in this volatile environment and that's really pushing through the segments as well. So, I think that's why you look Q2 going into Q3 you saw our management up quite a bit, you saw Fuel Systems up quite a bit as well and I think it's really a function of what we're seeing from both on a revenue and cost recovery perspective.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "c56dc3c3-faeb-40fd-9dd8-3fd2a429963d", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. Great. Super-helpful. And then if we move to the EV outlook and obviously the $4 billion revenue, really appreciate the consistency as you guys are updating. Just in terms of the methodology, we are -- as we see global EV volumes increasing, can you just talk about how often you're marking-to-market sort of '24, '25 assumptions on base business, is that something to assume on a quarterly basis, a yearly basis, just curious when you're booking the business obviously if projections go up, if that's a benefit? And then just a second, anything you could add on what you're seeing in Europe for EV outlook maybe next year.

So, the way we compute those EV wins is we look at the individual businesses, the volume that we are booking, the business at. We sometime apply some Market Intelligence adjustments and that's how we are monitoring the 2025 organic revenue bookings. As far as your second question around Europe, I would say overall EV is accelerating, and we can see that in the marketplace, we can see that with the intensity with which we are discussing with our customers, and we can see that with our business too. And that also applies for Europe, and very happy to see our growth in EV being across the three continents and also across a pretty sizable product portfolio.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "3b168271-c731-45fa-8ca0-beb2a4579562", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. Great. Thanks a lot guys.

Thank you for taking the question. I apologize if you addressed this in the prepared comments, I arrived a late here, but so just wondering first question regarding the granting of increased production on the inverter award that you disclosed this quarter, is it possible to give us a better feel of how widespread this sort of activity might be going forward especially thinking relative to the 2025 organic EV awards that you've booked already, are we talking tens of millions or maybe even hundreds of millions of potential upside from these sorts of activities?

Yeah, it is, I won't quantify that but it's sizable. And I would say that this is not a one-off. There is a lot of discussions with uplifting volumes, and I would say that one thing that is important is that the scale that we have in electronics and in power electronics in both purchasing and manufacturing electronics and power electronics allows us to offer our customers specific supply chain that are not intertwined. And so, I think this is a very, very good success for us. It enforces the fact that we have great products, great efficiency and also that resiliency of our supply chain is something that our customers have trust in.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "65887d98-1a36-424e-977b-1de37e8d137d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. That's helpful. And then it kind of leads into my second question on the e-axle awards. So, you said in the release that this can scale up to 7.5 tons trucks, wondering was that the customer-specific need or could you scale that up to even larger trucks with your current portfolio? And then a related question, bigger picture, just wondering how important scale is in the e-motor business as it relates to pursuing commercial vehicle opportunities, can you leverage your scale in light vehicle as you go into that world, clearly very important in power electronics, just wondering how transferable that would be in commercial vehicle as well on e-motor? Thank you.

Yeah, no for sure our motors can go above 7.5 tons, and this came from the customer specification, our motors can go much higher than that. And yes, the answer to your second question is, absolutely yes. Scale matters in CV for product leadership, but also competitiveness. This is a strategy that has been applied at BorgWarner for many, many years where we have numerous products that cut across past cars and commercial vehicle, we learn from both segments, and we can offer our commercial vehicle customers products that one fit for their function but also are competitive because we have that scale.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "20e36009-0577-4ee6-bb8d-5d64e07587ce", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: I will leave it there. Thank you.
Yeah, Luke.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "c46b3973-193d-46d2-9737-b560ab5f5f24", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Hi, team. This is Gavin Kennedy on for David Kelley. First question, can you just remind us of your disposition strategy, I believe prior expectations for $3.5 billion in targeted dispositions by 2025.

Yeah, that's still part of our Charging Forward plan. As I mentioned last quarter the challenging end-market environment really disrupted those potential disposition processes in the short-term and that's really due to two things. The uncertainty in industry production and the inflationary impacts on how those are going to play-out impacts potential buyers in those types of businesses in the near-term. And second, there's obviously challenges in the capital markets and the financing markets more generally. So those things have really slowed down our ability to transact over the last couple of quarters, but it doesn't change the direction where we're headed over time here, that pause is okay, because as you know we have a lot of high-quality cash flow generating assets in our portfolio, so we're not under pressure at all to sell anything and we're perfectly content to continue to generate the benefits of the cash flows from those businesses and then assess those as the market situation improves to look at reengaging in some of those disposition processes to make sure that we deliver a disposition that's going to generate appropriate value for our shareholders. But until the markets clear up from that, we're perfectly contend to continue to generate strong cash flows from these businesses.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "778bce87-b7f4-431c-b5e0-aa8e1169e3e9", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Got it. That makes sense. And then as a follow-up switching gears, you raised your DC fast-charging expectations to $225 million to $275 million by 2025, which is good to see. Can you give us any commentary on margins today and expectations for margins going forward as these charging business scale? Thank you.

We are not giving margin guidance yet as it relates to any of the specific acquisitions, but I think you know the strategy of BorgWarner and establishing product leadership as we get into different product categories and driving top-quartile margin performance as a company over time, so you should expect that as we get into any of these product lines that the expectations for what we ultimately deliver financially on those products is the same as what we expect to deliver from all parts of our business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "2af64781-a455-4975-bf3b-931d5cac413f", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Great. Thanks everyone.

Hi, guys. I wanted to ask about AKASOL. You noted as you know as a growth driver in Europe, and so wanted to first ask about the revenue trajectory maybe just any color relative to the targets that you laid out for AKASOL, then also as it relates to IRA and the battery, the battery pack assembly credit is there an opportunity for AKASOL to benefit at least from the 10 kilowatt-hour -- $10 per kilowatt-hour portion of that of that subsidy in the U.S.?

James, we get a lot of good customer pool for full battery packs from AKASOL. We are increasing year-over-year about $200 million from '21 to '22, and we're pretty confident that this business is going to go to plan. We have the right technology, we are going to expand AKASOL, we are actually expanding AKASOL as we speak in North America. And these products really are answering a lot of our customers questions and filling a lot of their needs, Kevin do you want to take the IRA question?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "c2bef785-8332-47d7-a907-a0f04405b572", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Yeah. I mean, we think there's a real opportunity for us to benefit from the IRA as we continue to invest to increase our capacity and manufacturing capability in the U.S., so we'll continue to look at the opportunities afforded by the Inflation Reduction Act and see what opportunities are afforded to us, but we think there's a real opportunity there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "519a815c-e6fd-43f0-8873-4d9a09161b09", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And AKASOL has been somewhat of a U.S. footprint, right. There was one facility, I believe.
Yeah, there is one facility in the U.S. right now in Michigan and we're looking at expanding the U.S. footprint actually as we speak.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "fdf3548b-e5bc-4c1c-873b-0e0acec1f3d4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Got it. Understood. And then for China, industry production obviously picked up pretty dramatically in the third quarter. It appears that there is some customer mix normalization of programs. Just curious is it tied to one or two important customers in China and is this something that's a sustained dynamic or something that could revert to the positive for you guys in terms of China production and your mix there?
I'm not sure I have that granularity for you. It seems at this point maybe Pat can follow-up with you offline, I don't know if I have a granularity for the Chinese country.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "0bfb119c-37cb-4260-ba76-038a111fed1d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: All right. Thank you.

Thank you very much, and many apologies for joining the call late, so if some of this was discussed before, I apologize. But I was curious if you could give us sort of high-level walk of third quarter to implied fourth quarter outlook, it looks great. You're basically calling for the lower revenues but also in the lower margins, and so just if could you just discuss some of the puts and takes there?
Were you saying both our growth and margin Emmanuel, is that what you said?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "c9b2cb60-e2ce-43db-93e9-43cb42a9b53e", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Revenue and margin.

Revenue and margin going Q3 to Q4. Yeah, I think as you look, let me start with revenue, as you go from Q3 to Q4 and you look at the range the $300 million range we're providing on revenue, at the upper end of that range, you'll see revenue a little bit down and that's really driven entirely by foreign exchange, it's about a $90 million headwind going sequentially from Q3 to Q4. If you look at the low end of the range, we're still assuming about that $90 million foreign exchange related headwind but then there's about $280 million sequential headwind in organic growth, so that's a way to think about revenue going through Q3 to Q4. When you look at margin, you've got to start by looking at Q3 that 10.8% and remember my comments earlier there is about 40 basis points of that margin coming from the net benefit of retroactive customer pricing recoveries net of the retroactive supplier cost increases. So that's about a 40-basis-point tailwind in Q3. So, as you then adjust Q3 and look ahead to Q4, take Q4 at the high end of our guide as relatively flat, maybe slightly up from that adjusted level, and if you look at the low end of our guide which is around 9.5% or so in Q4 it's really jumping off that adjusted Q3 level and then recognizing that we have downside conversion on that roughly $280 million organic decline sequentially. And that's how you really get to the math of it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "9845746d-2f79-4707-aae4-1650de2b7831", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And the $280 million headwind sequentially fell, if could you please just provide a little bit more color and apologize if I missed it.

I'm sorry, what's really driving the sequential is the production assumptions that are underlying the guide. I mean, so at the low-end of the range you can see that production is down sequentially going from Q3 to Q4.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "2a561ae5-90a9-4114-8c38-80e98e59f5a5", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And that thing represents the volatility that still exist in this marketplace and especially I would say in Q4 especially in Europe with everything that is happening so taking that in consideration also in our Q4 top line, again which is little a little wider than usual, but it represents the market environment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "ce53aecf-210d-4af1-9d37-10e9bf328bf8", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Yes, so if you're looking at like IHS as an example, our Q4 at the low-end of the range is almost 1 million units below IHS from a light-vehicle perspective globally.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "6ba6e9d3-120d-47fe-8a73-737cb3403415", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. That's helpful. And then I was hoping to ask you about your free cash flow use priorities in the current environment, you obviously mentioned, disruptive environment for dispositions. I assume that some of that applies to acquisitions as well, so is this a kind of environment where return to shareholders will be prioritized, or would you rather serve like powder dry for future uses on the M&A side?

Yeah, I mean you can obviously see we've been deploying cash in a couple different ways over the course of 2022, we've been executing on our acquisition strategy as we've communicated as part of Charging Forward with the deals that we've done to-date this year and we've also been repurchasing stock as well, $100 million in the quarter which means it's $440 million year-to-date, and so we've been pleased with deploying cash to support both of those objectives, while we continue to assess the right moments to be opportunistic stake in buying back our stock, I'd say as you look ahead, I want to continue to emphasize what we've been emphasizing in prior quarters that investing in attractive electrification opportunities including M&A is really the near-term priority for our uses of capital, that's what we're going to focus it as a priority.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "e0fadc80-0484-4370-bd94-bec7e390c1f0", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: All right. Thank you.

Thanks so much for squeezing me in everyone. Fred, maybe just first to go back to some of your comments on IRA, the expansion of AKASOL in the U.S. or the potential expansion, is that sort of a BorgWarner initiative or is that something being driven by customer demand, asking you to sort of help build that out? And then also I know like the IRA build sort of talks about inverters really more in a solar sense, but we've heard that there is some, and I guess we'll wait for treasury ruling, but we've heard there's some talk that maybe that could apply for vehicles as well, so do you think there's any opportunity in that bill from inverters and or even charging hardware?

Yeah, Joe first, the expansion in the U.S. is definitely driven by program secured with the customers that we've had when we acquired. AKASOL plus new customers that we've announced over the past quarters. Kevin, do you want to take this...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "2e24010b-220e-4033-81e1-8cc3958eedea", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Yeah, in terms of your question about inverters, I think based on our read of the legislation to-date and our understanding of it, it doesn't apply to the inverters for automotive. I think the opportunity for us as it relates to IRA is really more around battery modules and battery packs, and so we're assessing that as we're looking to increase our manufacturing footprint here in the U.S. to support our customer demands.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "67e18034-fef8-4e10-93b5-53c811af8324", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Would you consider inverters for solar applications or it's sort of a different competency?

They are slightly different, but not dramatically different. Actually, it's part of our acquisition of SSE, it's part of some challenging integration that they do, they include solar battery pack and charges and that might be something that we look at. I would tell you that it's not currently the priority but in the future that might be a nice diversification going forward based on the current technology.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Frederic B. Lissalde", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "29077b77-a7b1-435e-b076-4916dbb12909", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Executive Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: Okay. And then I guess just finally you've talked about the sort of overall enterprise level R&D and had some of the changes there. I was wondering though if, I mean it seems to me, but correct me if I'm wrong that like that's sort of predominantly centered in that e-Propulsion and Drivetrain segment, and I was wondering if you could give us a sense of like how much of a basis point drag has sort of that additional step-up investment in a way specifically in that segment?

Yeah. I mean if you look at -- you're right the e-product related R&D is disproportionately in the e-Propulsion and Drivetrain segment, and so when you look at our e-products investment to-date it's been over $300 million and for the full year it will be over $400 million, and the bulk of that is really coming in that segment, and so that you can really see the impact that that's had on the margins of that business. Now as we look ahead to 2023, we would expect that as our EV revenue is growing that we would expect the contribution margins on that growth in EV revenue to be growing at a faster pace than our e-products related R&D, and so we'll start to get some improvement in margin in that segment as that contribution grows at a faster pace than our e-products related R&D.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Kevin Nowlan", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "3edc93c6-dfa0-4e63-bc17-394114d7b9f0", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at BorgWarner"}

section.text: And that R&D Kevin really is sort of engineering ahead of launch or is it sort of some more like research type for future product, how should we think about how quickly you'll start getting return on that spent?
